The hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol not only lessens CO2 emission but also relieves energy shortage, and Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst has been found to have excellent activity. However, there is a large amount of water generated in CO2 hydrogenation, which causes the catalyst to be in severe hydrothermal environment during the reaction, and then leads to the deactivation of catalyst. And the effect of hydrothermal environment on Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol is often neglected. In this work, the catalyst Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 was prepared by coprecipitation method, and then was underwent hydrothermal treatments with different times and temperatures. After that, the changes of catalyst structures and surface properties due to the hydrothermal treatments were studied in detail by various characterization technologies. At last, these catalysts were used in CO2 hydrogenation into methanol to show the effect of hydrothermal treatments on catalytic activity and selectivity. Graphical abstract Hydrothermal environment resulted in the agglomeration of Cu and ZnO in Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst, and then decreased SCu, which decreased catalytic activity. In addition, compared with the more hydrothermal treatment time, the higher hydrothermal treatment temperature showed more seriously effect on the structure and surface properties of Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst, which decreased the strength and quantity of CO2 and H2 adsorption, resulting in the further decrease of CO2 conversion. Meanwhile, hydrothermal environment decreased the interface between Cu and CO2 adsorption sites due to the growth of Cu and Zn particles, which greatly inhibited methanol generation. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Cu-ZnO Hydrothermal environment CO2 Hydrogenation Methanol Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction A large amount of CO2 from the fossil fuels is releasing explosively into atmosphere, resulting in many serious environmental problems, so more and more governments and institutions are placing more and more emphasis on the reduction of CO2 emission [1–6]. As an abundant and cheap C1 source, CO2 could be converted into methanol, dimethyl ether, formic acid, olefins and ethanol by hydrogenation in recent years, which will not only alleviate the emission of CO2, but also achieve the reutilization of carbon resource [7–11]. As a clean and convenient liquid fuel, methanol produced from the hydrogenation of CO2 can relieve the energy shortage, and more importantly, it can be used as raw material to synthesize many other chemical products, for example olefins, gasoline and formaldehyde [12–16]. Therefore, CO2 hydrogenation to methanol has attracted widespread attention recently. Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst has been found to have good catalytic activity in the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol, and one-pass CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity could reach 95% and 98% at 36 MPa, respectively [17], which has been studied widely by many researchers. For example, the study on methanol generation over industrial catalyst Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 showed that the active site was formed by Cu steps and neighboring Znδ+ atoms, which were stabilized by bulk defects and dynamic strong metal-support interaction effect, respectively [18]. And the ZnO/Cu interfaces with oxygen vacancies were considered to be essential to catalytic activation [19]. In our previous work, the surface basicity of Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 was found to strengthen CO2 adsorption and weaken methanol adsorption, meanwhile, it inhibited the dissociation of methanol to CO, which promoted the hydrogenation of CO2 into methanol [20]. To obtain excellent catalytic activity at mild conditions, many new synthetic strategies of Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts for the hydrogenation of CO2 have been reported, for instance, the catalyst Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 with addition of ZrO2 or CeO2 was found to significantly improve conversion of CO2 and selectivity to methanol due to the increased active Cu surface area and surface basicity [21–25]. In addition, Cu/ZnO catalyst with introduction of Ga3+ also enhanced CO2 hydrogenation to methanol due to the deep reduction of ZnO [26]. And Cu0/Cu+ ratio in Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts could be controlled via suitable NaBH4 content in the process of precipitation-reduction, which significantly increased methanol selectivity [27]. However, the catalytic activity over the most of catalysts in above-mentioned reports would begin to decrease after about 100 h during the long-term testing, which prevented the industrial processes of CO2 hydrogenation. Most of studies on Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 deactivation in hydrogenation of CO2 showed that the main reasons were carbon deposition, trace impurity and Cu particle sinter [21,28]. In addition, the restructuring of some ZnO in catalyst would result in the deactivation of Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 according to the work form Lunkenbein et al. [29]. In fact, there is a large amount of water generated in CO2 hydrogenation, which causes the catalysts to be in severe hydrothermal environment during the reaction. It had been reported that the support in supported metal catalyst would be hydrolyzed in hydrothermal environment, which leaded to pore structures collapse and active metal aggregation, and then resulted in the deactivation of catalyst [30–32]. However, the effect of hydrothermal environment on Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst for hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol was rarely reported. A similar industrial catalyst Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 was obtained by coprecipitation method in this work, which would undergo the hydrothermal treatments with different times and temperatures. The changes of catalyst structures and surface properties due to the hydrothermal treatments were studied in detail by various testing techniques. At last, these catalysts were used in the hydrogenation of CO2 to expose the effect of hydrothermal treatments on catalytic activity and selectivity of the Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalyst The catalyst Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 with about 50 wt.% Cu and 20 wt.% ZnO was obtained by coprecipitation method as reported in our previous work [20]. Specifically, 7.3 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, 19.0 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 22.1 g of Al(NO3)3·9H2O were completely dissolved in 150 mL of deionized water under ultrasound irradiation. Meanwhile, another 150 of mL aqueous solution with 24.4 g of Na2CO3 were obtained in the same way, and then they were slowly dripped in 500 mL of deionized water at 358 K with vigorous stirring conditions. After aging for 0.5 h, a precipitate was obtained, and then was washed to neutral in deionized water. The precipitate was dried in n-butanol solution at 373 K, which could increase metallic particles dispersion [33,34]. Then, the powder sample was sieved into 40–60 meshes by tableting and crushing. The catalyst was firstly reduced by 20 vol.% H2/N2 for 2 h at 573 K, and then was protected by N2 and transferred into 30 mL of deionized water in a hydrothermal reactor (100 mL), and then was heated for stated time and temperature, in which the catalyst should be still in liquid water in the process of hydrothermal treatment. The catalyst was filtered after cooling to room temperature, and then dried at 393 K. The catalysts with hydrothermally treatment at 453 K for 5 and 10 h were termed as CZA-t5 and CZA-t10, respectively, and the catalysts treated for 5 h at 453, 493 and 533 K were termed as CZA-453, CZA-493 and CZA-533, respectively. Some of the metallic Cu in the catalyst would be inevitably oxidized in the process of hydrothermal treatment. And all the catalysts were again reduced by 10 vol.% H2/N2 for 1 h at 573 K for measurement and reaction. For better comparison, the catalyst without hydrothermal treatment was still reduced again at same condition (10 vol.% H2/N2 for 1 h at 573 K) for measurement and reaction, which was termed as CZA. 2.2 Characterizations of catalyst The crystalline structural information of CZA catalyst was tested by X-ray diffraction (XRD) over a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5408 Å). The loading of Cu over CZA catalyst was determined over an ARL-9800 X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometer. Before characterization of the pore structure including pore sizes and surface areas, the catalyst was degassed in flowing N2 for 4 h at 523 K, and then tested at 77.3 K over a Gemini V 2380 auto-sorption analyzer. The pore size distribution was obtained via Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, and the specific surface area was analyzed via Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The catalysts morphology was acquired over a JEOL 2100F transmission electron microscope (TEM), and the accelerating voltage was 200 kV. The element mapping analyses of the catalysts were performed over FE-SEM (Sigma 300, Oxford Xplore 30). Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was performed on a chemisorption analyzer (AMI-300, Altamira) with about 25 mg of the calcined samples in 10 vol.% H2/Ar at a flow rate of 30 mL/min. The reduction temperatures were from 323 to 673 K and the heating rate was 10 K/min. The exposed Cu surface area (SCu) over CZA catalyst could be also measured over the AMI-300 chemisorption analyzer. At first, m g of catalyst was reduced in flowing 10 vol.% H2/Ar for 1 h at 573 K. After the sample temperature dropped to 343 K in flowing Ar, the reduced catalyst would be exposed into flowing 10 vol% N2O/Ar for 1 h, which would make the surface Cu° completely oxidize into surface Cu+. Then, the catalyst would be reduced again by 10 vol.% H2/Ar. The amount of consumed H2 for the reduction of surface Cu+ species was recorded, which could be termed as n, and the SCu was calculated as the following equation [7]: S Cu = ( 2 n × 6.022 × 10 23 ) / ( m × 1.47 × 10 19 ) ( m 2 / g ) Microcalorimetric measurements of CO, CO2, H2 and methanol molecules adsorbed on the surface of the CZA catalyst were carried out over a Setaram C-80 microcalorimeter, and the pressure measurements and gas handling were achieved by a glass vacuum system and MKS baratron capacitance manometer [35,36]. Before the measurement, the catalyst was first reduced for 1 h at 573 K in flowing 10 vol% H2/Ar, and then evacuated for 1 h at 573 K. The X-ray-induced Auger spectra (XAES) of CZA catalyst were recorded over a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with Al Kα radiation excitation source, and pass energy was 50 eV. Prior to XAES measurement, the catalysts were reduced for 1 h at 573 K and protected by high-purity N2. After evacuating for 0.5 h at 573 K, Zn and Cu LMM spectra treated with pure CO2 at 513 K were collected, which were calibrated to C 1 s peak at 284.5 eV. 2.3 Activity tests of catalyst The hydrogenation of CO2 into methanol was performed in a fixed-bed reactor with 0.25 g of catalyst sandwiched with quartz sands (60–80 meshes). Before the reaction, the catalyst was reduced for 1 h at 573 K by a flowing 10 vol% H2/N2 under normal pressure. The reaction gas of H2, CO2 and N2 flowed into the reactor, and flow rate was 65 mL/min with the volume ratio of 9/3/1. The hydrogenation of CO2 was performed at GHSV = 15,600 mL h−1 g−1 and P = 5.0 MPa, and N2 was internal standard. The results of activity tests were obtained based on the average of three independent tests over an online gas chromatograph (Lunan SP-6890) equipped with thermal conductivity detector and flame ionization detector (the errors were not more than ± 3%), which were analyzed as follows [23,37]: X = moles C O 2 ( in ) moles N 2 ( in ) − moles C O 2 ( out ) moles N 2 ( out ) moles C O 2 ( in ) moles N 2 ( in ) × 100 % S MeOH = moles MeOH moles MeOH + moles CO × 100 % S CO = moles CO moles MeOH + moles CO × 100 % ST Y MeOH = X × S MeOH × moles C O 2 ( in ) m cat . × t × 100 % ST Y CO = X × S CO × moles C O 2 ( in ) m cat . × t × 100 % TO F MeOH = ST Y MeOH × N A S Cu × 1.47 × 10 19 atoms / m 2 × 100 where mcat. was the catalyst weight (g), t was the reaction time (h) and NA was Avogadro's number (6.02 × 1023 mol−1). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of hydrothermal treatment with different times on catalyst structure Fig. 1 is the XRD patterns of CZA with hydrothermal treatment for different times at 453 K, which could be used to study the crystalline structures. For fresh catalyst CZA, the diffraction peaks for metallic Cu (JCPDS 01-1241) at around 43.4°, 50.5° and 74.2° were observed, and the Cu crystal size estimated form full width of half maximum at 43.4° by Scherrer equation was about 7.6 nm. Meanwhile, the diffraction peaks at around 31.8°, 34.5°, 36.3° and 56.6° were recorded, which were assigned to crystalline ZnO (JCPDS 01-1136), and the ZnO crystal size estimated form full width of half maximum at 36.3° by Scherrer equation was about 4.5 nm. After hydrothermal treatment for 5 h at 453 K, it was seen that the intensity of diffraction peaks for Cu in CZA-t5 catalyst enhanced significantly, and the Cu crystal size estimated by Scherrer equation increased into 17.2 nm. Meanwhile, the intensity of ZnO diffraction peaks also enhanced, and new diffraction peaks around 62.9°, 67.8° and 69.1° from ZnO crystal were observed, indicating that ZnO crystal grew larger due to the hydrothermal treatment, which increased into about 10.5 nm estimated by Scherrer equation. When the time of hydrothermal treatment was lengthened to 10 h, Cu and ZnO diffraction peaks in CZA-t10 had less change, in which the sizes of Cu and ZnO crystal were 20.2 and 11.0 nm, respectively. Due to the amorphous structure of Al2O3 and strong diffraction peaks of Cu and ZnO, the hydrated alumina could not be detected in XRD test. However, it had been reported that the Al2O3 in supported catalysts could be hydrated to AlOOH or Al(OH)3 species in hydrothermal environment, and it would change the structure and surface properties of supported catalysts, which leaded to the agglomeration of nanoparticles. It could be seen that the more time of hydrothermal treatment resulted in the more obvious agglomeration of Cu and ZnO particles in CZA catalyst. The Cu loading in these catalysts was determined via XRF, which is shown in Table 1 . It could be found that the Cu loading decreased because of hydrothermal treatment, and more treatment time would further decrease the Cu loading. Fig. 2 A shows N2 sorption isotherms of CZA with hydrothermal treatment for different times at 453 K. They gave type-IV isotherms and had an H3 hysteresis loops. And Fig. 2B shows pore size distributions of these catalyst, exhibiting the presence of mesoporous structure. The detailed data of surface areas and pore structures are shown in Table 1. It could be found that the surface areas would be diminished markedly after hydrothermal treatment, and the pore size and pore volume also were decreased, showing that hydrothermal treatment would destroy the pore structure. SCu of supported Cu catalyst was confirmed to be an important factor in improving the hydrogenation of CO2 into methanol [20], and the SCu also was decreased due to the hydrothermal treatment, as shown in Table 1, which should result from the more agglomeration of metallic Cu and decrease of surface area [21]. 3.2 Effect of hydrothermal treatment with different temperatures on catalyst structure Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of CZA with hydrothermal treatment for 5 h at different temperatures. And the XRD patterns of fresh catalyst CZA and CZA-453 with hydrothermal treatment at 453 K had been shown in previous section, i.e., the XRD patterns of CZA and CZA-t5 in Fig. 1, respectively. In addition, it could be seen that the intensity of Cu diffraction peaks was further enhanced with hydrothermal treatment temperature increasing, and Cu crystal size was estimated to be 26.3 and 29.6 nm by Scherrer equation at 493 K and 533 K, respectively, which grew faster than that hydrothermal treated with more time, showing the more serious effect on Cu particles from higher hydrothermal treatment temperature. But the intensity of diffraction peaks for ZnO almost had no change after hydrothermal treatment at higher temperature, indicating that the higher hydrothermal treatment temperature would not affect the ZnO crystalline particles. As shown in Table 2 , Cu loading measured by XRF was decreased after hydrothermal treatment at higher temperature, and the diminution was more than those after hydrothermal treatment with more time, indicating that the higher hydrothermal treatment temperature would result in the more loss of Cu. Fig. 4 A shows N2 sorption isotherms of CZA with hydrothermal treatment for 5 h at different temperatures. They still gave type-IV isotherms and had an H3 hysteresis loops. As shown in Fig. 4B, the pore size distributions of these catalyst still exhibited the presence of mesoporous structure. The detailed dates of surface areas and pore structures are shown in Table 2. The results indicated that the surface area was decreased obviously as the increase of hydrothermal treatment temperature, which was reduced to 56 m2/g after hydrothermal treatment for 5 h at 533 K, meanwhile, the pore volume and diameter also were decreased sharply. Besides, the SCu was reduced to 10.4 m2/g over CZA-533 from 27.5 m2/g over CZA. These results revealed that the influence of higher temperature on catalyst was more serious than that of more time during hydrothermal treatment process. Fig. 5 is TEM images of CZA, CZA-453, CZA-493 and CZA-533, which could be used to direct show the crystalline of ZnO and Cu. As shown in the high-resolution image inserted in Fig. 5A, the lattice fringe with a d -spacing of 0.28 nm was compatible with (101) planes of ZnO in CZA, and that of 0.21 nm was compatible with (111) planes of metallic Cu [37]. Hence, the dark particles in TEM images should be ZnO or Cu, which were distributed uniformly in CZA from Fig. 5A. After hydrothermal treatment at 453 K, there were dark particles with different sizes in Fig. 5B, and the large particles should be Cu particles according to the results of XRD, showing that the hydrothermal treatment resulted in the agglomeration of Cu nano-particles. In addition, the agglomeration of Cu nano-particles was more obvious with hydrothermal treatment temperature increasing from Fig. 5C and D, indicating that the higher temperature of hydrothermal treatment greatly promoted the growth of Cu nano-particles, which leaded to the more decrease of SCu. In addition, SEM image also can be used to directly observe the morphologic structure of the catalyst. Fig. 5E is the SEM image of CZA-533 catalyst, and it could be seen that many large particles were observed. Meanwhile, the element distribution in CZA-533 catalyst could be characterized by SEM-EDX, which is shown in Fig. 5F–I, and all the present elements (Cu, Zn, Al and O) were distributed homogeneously on the surface of CZA-533 catalyst. Based on the element distribution, it could be confirmed that these large particles were mainly from metallic copper particles, and it further showed the growth of metal copper particles, which was coincided with the results of TEM. The interaction between the Cu and support can be studied by H2-TPR, and Fig. 6 shows the H2-TPR results of these samples with calcination by 0.5 vol.% O2/N2 at 523 K for 2 h. In CZA, the profiles can be deconvoluted into three Gaussian peaks, which were denoted as α, β and γ peak. The α peak could be attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed CuO species on the catalyst surface, and the β and γ peaks were from the reduction of CuO species weakly and strongly interacted with support, respectively [9,16,20]. And it was found that the reduction peaks of CZA-453 with hydrothermal treatment at 453 K were shifted to lower temperatures. When the temperature of hydrothermal treatment was further increased, the corresponding reduction peaks were further shifted to lower temperatures, indicating that the hydrothermal treatment weakened the interaction of Cu and support. More importantly, the highly dispersed CuO species on the catalyst surface was disappeared on the surface of CZA-493 and CZA-533, and they should be agglomerated to large particles due to the structural damage of CZA catalyst in hydrothermal treatment [30], which was consistent with TEM results. The H2 consumption amounts of these catalysts were listed in Table 3 , and it could be found that they were decreased with the increase of hydrothermal treatment temperature, and the reducibility was also decreased correspondingly, which should result in the decrease of SCu. 3.3 Effect of hydrothermal treatment on surface properties CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity in CO2 hydrogenation had been found to be related to the surface properties of Cu-ZnO catalysts [20,38]. The change of electron density on metallic Cu surface could be illustrated by the microcalorimetric adsorption of CO [22,31,32], and the microcalorimetric adsorption of CO over CZA catalyst with hydrothermal treatment at different temperatures was measured, which was used to study the effect of hydrothermal treatment on surface properties over CZA. From the result of CO microcalorimetric adsorption as shown in Fig. 7 , the initial heat of CO adsorption over the fresh catalyst CZA was 65 kJ/mol, meanwhile, the corresponding coverage was 53 μmol/g. The initial heat of CO adsorption over CZA-453 with hydrothermal treatment at 453 K was reduced into 55 kJ/mol, and the coverage was decreased to 34 μmol/g. When hydrothermal treatment temperature continued to increase, the initial heats of CO adsorption were reduced into 44 and 38 kJ/mol, and the corresponding coverages were decreased to 22 and 19 μmol/g over CZA-493 and CZA-533, respectively. Obviously, hydrothermal treatment made the initial heat and coverage of CO adsorption decrease, indicating that the quantity and strength of CO adsorption on metallic Cu surface were reduced significantly after hydrothermal environment, and the higher hydrothermal treatment temperature would lead to the further decrease, which should result from the more growth of Cu nanoparticles. The decrease of CO adsorption strength revealed the decrease of electron density over Cu, and the decrease of CO adsorption quantity showed the decrease of CO adsorption sites. As the main by-product, the weaker and less adsorption of CO on the Cu surface accelerated the desorption of CO from catalyst surface in CO2 hydrogenation, which promoted the generation of CO and then decreased methanol selectivity [22]. The adsorption of CO2 and H2 onto the supported Cu catalyst affected the activity of CO2 hydrogenation, and the change of surface chemistry properties resulted from hydrothermal treatment would affect the adsorption of CO2 and H2 [20]. Fig. 8 A shows the result of CO2 microcalorimetric adsorption at 453 K. It could be seen that the initial heat of CO2 adsorption over CZA without hydrothermal treatment was 75 kJ/mol, and the corresponding coverage could be up to 93 μmol/g, which were reduced into 60 kJ/mol and 79 μmol/g over CZA-453, respectively. When the temperature of hydrothermal treatment was rose to 493 and 513 K, the initial heats of CO2 adsorption were reduced into 46 and 40 kJ/mol, respectively. Correspondingly, the coverages were reduced into 46 and 35 μmol/g, respectively. According to the literature, CO2 molecules were mainly adsorbed on support surface, and ZnO in catalyst could promote the adsorption of CO2 molecules [21]. Hence, the decrease of strength and quantity of CO2 adsorption over the catalyst might result from the growth of ZnO according to the results of XRD, which was not beneficial for CO2 activation [20]. The microcalorimetric adsorption of H2 was too weak over Cu at room temperature, which was difficult to be identified accurately. Hence, the microcalorimetric adsorption for dissociated H2 over supported Cu at 423 K was measured in this work. The initial heat of dissociated H2 adsorbed onto the fresh catalyst CZA was 118 kJ/mol, and the corresponding coverage was 48 μmol/g from Fig. 8B, which were reduced into 103 kJ/mol and 35 μmol/g over CZA-453, respectively. When the temperature of hydrothermal treatment was rose to 493 and 513 K, the initial heats for adsorption of dissociated H2 were reduced into 85 and 49 kJ/mol, and the corresponding coverages were decreased to 20 and 13 μmol/g on the catalysts CZA-493 and CZA-533, respectively. It was seen that the higher hydrothermal treatment temperature would greatly inhibit the dissociation adsorption of H2, which should result from the decrease of SCu as shown in Table 2. In hydrogenation of CO2, H2 molecules were dissociated by active metallic Cu, and the less quantity of H2 adsorption should be not beneficial for the hydrogenation of intermediate species from activated CO2 [20,25]. As the target product in CO2 hydrogenation, methanol desorption would improve the selectivity to methanol [20]. Fig. 9 shows the microcalorimetric adsorption of methanol at 303 K. The initial heat of methanol adsorption over the fresh catalyst CZA was 103 kJ/mol, and the corresponding coverage was 398 μmol/g, which were reduced into 92 kJ/mol and 326 μmol/g over CZA-453, respectively. When the temperature of hydrothermal treatment was rose to 493 and 513 K, the initial heats of methanol adsorption were reduced into 65 and 50 kJ/mol, meanwhile, their coverages were diminished to 186 and 151 μmol/g on CZA-493 and CZA-533, respectively, indicating that the hydrothermal treatment promoted methanol desorption from the surface of CZA catalyst. 3.4 Activity test for the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol Fig. 10 A shows the conversion of CO2 on the CZA catalysts with hydrothermal treatment at different reaction temperatures, and it could be seen that CO2 conversion was raised rapidly on all catalysts when the reaction temperature rose, indicating that the higher reaction temperature would promote CO2 conversion. However, CO2 conversion on these catalysts with hydrothermal treatment at different temperatures could be found as follows: CZA > CZA-453 > CZA-493 > CZA-533, revealing that hydrothermal treatment would decrease the CO2 conversion over the supported Cu catalyst, and the higher temperature of hydrothermal treatment would lead to the lower CO2 conversion. According to the literatures, the high SCu over supported Cu catalyst promoted the conversion of CO2 by H2 activation and spillover on Cu [25,39], and the SCu over CZA was found to be reduced when the temperature of hydrothermal treatment was increased in this work, and thus resulted in the lower CO2 conversion. Meanwhile, the strength and quantity of CO2 adsorption over the supported Cu catalyst were decreased due to the change of structure and surface properties due to the hydrothermal treatment, which would further decrease CO2 conversion. Finally, the CO2 conversion was diminished greatly on the supported Cu catalysts due to hydrothermal treatment. Fig. 10B shows methanol selectivity over the supported Cu catalysts with hydrothermal treatment at different reaction temperatures. The methanol selectivity was reduced rapidly on these catalysts when the reaction temperature rose, indicating that the higher reaction temperature would inhibit the production of methanol. In addition, it could be found that the methanol selectivity on CZA catalyst with hydrothermal treatment at different temperatures was as follows: CZA > CZA-453 > CZA-493 > CZA-533. The adsorption of methanol was weakened by the hydrothermal treatment, which should promote methanol desorption and then heighten the selectivity to methanol [20]. But the hydrothermal treatment evidently decreased methanol selectivity in this work, and the higher temperature of hydrothermal treatment would further decrease the methanol selectivity. As the target product, methanol was generated at interface of ZnO and Cu via the hydrogenation of *HCOO intermediate species from activated CO2 and spillover hydrogen [25,40,41]. Obviously, the interface of ZnO and Cu would affect the production of methanol, and the hydrothermal treatment had been found to make Cu and ZnO particles grow from the results of TEM and XRD characterizations, which destroyed the interface structure of Cu and ZnO, and then decreased the methanol selectivity. CO was the main by-product in this work. Fig. 10C is the selectivity to CO over these catalysts with hydrothermal treatment at different reaction temperatures. It could be found that the selectivity to CO was raised rapidly on all the catalysts when the reaction temperature rose, indicating that the more CO2 molecules would be converted to CO at higher reaction temperature, which leaded to the decrease of methanol selectivity. Meanwhile, CO selectivity on CZA catalyst with hydrothermal treatment at different temperatures could be found as follows: CZA-533 > CZA-493 > CZA-453 > CZA, revealing that the hydrothermal treatment promoted CO2 conversion into CO on supported Cu catalyst. Due to the change of surface properties by hydrothermal treatment, CO adsorption was greatly weakened, which would promote the desorption of CO during the reaction. Besides, the higher hydrothermal treatment temperature resulted in the greater damage of interface structure between Cu with ZnO, which would inhibit the hydrogenation of intermediate species from activated CO2 [40], resulting in the higher selectivity to CO and the lower selectivity to methanol. Based on CO2 conversion and methanol and CO selectivity, STYMeOH and STYCO at different reaction temperatures over the supported Cu catalysts were obtained. As shown in Fig. 11 , the STYMeOH on CZA increased as the reaction temperature rose until 513 K because of increased conversion of CO2, but STYMeOH on other catalysts after hydrothermal treatment reached the maximum value at 493 K from Fig. 11A when the reaction temperature was further raised, the STYMeOH on these catalysts was decreased gradually due to the greatly increased selectivity to CO. In addition, it could be found that the STYMeOH on CZA catalyst with hydrothermal treatment at different temperatures was as follows: CZA > CZA-453 > CZA-493 > CZA-533, showing that hydrothermal treatment with higher temperature would further decrease the STYMeOH due to the decrease of CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity. When the reaction temperature increased, STYCO on these supported Cu catalysts was increased monotonically because of the increased selectivity to CO as shown in Fig. 11B, indicating that higher reaction temperature made more CO2 molecules convert to CO by reverse water-gas shift reaction in CO2 hydrogenation. Meanwhile, it could be found that the STYCO on CZA catalyst with hydrothermal treatment at different temperatures was as follows: CZA > CZA-453 > CZA-493 > CZA-533, revealing that the hydrothermal treatment with higher temperature also resulted in the more decrease of STYCO. It was reported that CO molecules were mainly from RWGS reaction, and high SCu accelerated the production of CO [21,42]. Hence, the decrease of STYCO on the supported Cu catalysts with hydrothermal treatment should result from the decrease of SCu. The turnover frequency of methanol (TOFMeOH) meant the number of methanol-molecule production on unit site of exposed copper atom per second (s−1), which could be calculated based on the SCu and STYMeOH. As shown in Fig. 11C, it could be found that the TOFMeOH over the catalyst was decreased with the increase of hydrothermal treatment temperature, especially at higher reaction temperatures, and this phenomenon was very close to the result of STYMeOH, which should be resulted from the decrease of SCu, and then slowed the hydrogenation process. The interface effect of Cu-ZnO had been found to be related to the activity of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, which could be studied by Cu and Zn chemical states [9,43]. To study the interface effect of CZA catalyst due to the hydrothermal treatment, Zn and Cu chemical states over these catalysts with CO2 adsorption at 493 K were tested via Zn and Cu LMM XAES spectra. Fig. 12 A is the XAES spectra of Zn LMM. There were two peaks at around 498.0 and 495.0 eV, which were attributed to the Zn2+ and Zn0 species, respectively [20,44]. It could be found that the strength of Zn LMM XAES spectra was strengthened with the increased temperature of hydrothermal treatment, which might result from Cu nanoparticles growth and then lead to more Zn species exposed to the catalyst surface. It was reported that some Zn2+ species would be reduced to Zn0 species via activated hydrogen on neighboring Cu on the surface of Cu-ZnO catalyst, and the higher Zn0/Zn2+ atom ratio revealed the more Cu-ZnO interfaces, which promoted the production of methanol by accelerating the hydrogenation of HCOO* species to CH3O* species through spilling of active hydrogen [25,45]. The Zn0/Zn2+ atom ratios acquired from the corresponding Gaussian peaks area over CZA, CZA-453, CZA-493 and CZM-533 catalysts were 0.15, 0.14, 0.13 and 0.11, respectively, obviously, they were decreased with the increased temperature of hydrothermal treatment, which were agreed with STYMeOH, and the results showed that the more Cu-ZnO interfaces promoted the production of methanol and hydrothermal treatment decreased the interface. In the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol, the Cu0 species at neighboring CO2 adsorption sites would be oxidized into Cu+ species by CO2, which should be related to CO2 activation. Fig. 12B shows the XAES spectra of Cu LMM on CZA, CZA-453, CZA-493 and CZM-533 catalysts with CO2 adsorption at 493 K.Two peaks were measured at about 570.1 and 568.2 eV, which should be from Cu+ and Cu0 species, respectively [9,22]. And the strength of Cu LMM XAES spectra was greatly weakened with the increased temperature of hydrothermal treatment, implying the decrease of surface Cu species over CZA catalyst with the increase of hydrothermal treatment temperature due to the growth of Cu nanoparticles, which further indicated that hydrothermal treatment would lead to the decrease of Cu dispersity on catalyst surface. The Cu+/Cu0 atom ratios obtained from the deconvolution were 4.80, 4.26, 4.13 and 3.65 over CZA, CZA-453, CZA-493 and CZM-533 catalysts, respectively, and they also were decreased with increased temperature of hydrothermal treatment, which were agreed with CO2 conversion, indicating that the hydrothermal treatment decreased the interface between Cu and CO2 adsorption sites, which decreased CO2 conversion. 4 Conclusion The catalyst Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 with 50 wt.% Cu loading synthesized by coprecipitation method was underwent hydrothermal treatments with different times and temperatures, and it could be found that the hydrothermal treatment resulted in the agglomeration of Cu and ZnO particles, especially metallic Cu particles, and then resulted in the decrease of SCu, which decreased catalytic activity. In addition, compared with the more hydrothermal treatment time, the higher hydrothermal treatment temperature showed more seriously effect on the catalyst structure. The change of catalyst structure resulted in the change of surface properties, and it would not only weaken the strength of CO2 and H2 adsorption but also decrease the quantity of CO2 and H2 adsorption over the catalyst, which would further decrease the conversion of CO2. Hydrothermal treatment weakened the adsorption of methanol, which should increase the methanol selectivity, but the interface between Cu and CO2 adsorption sites should be the key to increasing methanol selectivity, which would be decreased because of the growth of Cu and Zn particles in the process of hydrothermal treatment, and thus greatly inhibited methanol generation. coredata.dc:description: The hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol not only lessens CO2 emission but also relieves energy shortage, and Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst has been found to have excellent activity. However, there is a large amount of water generated in CO2 hydrogenation, which causes the catalyst to be in severe hydrothermal environment during the reaction, and then leads to the deactivation of catalyst. And the effect of hydrothermal environment on Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol is often neglected. In this work, the catalyst Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 was prepared by coprecipitation method, and then was underwent hydrothermal treatments with different times and temperatures. After that, the changes of catalyst structures and surface properties due to the hydrothermal treatments were studied in detail by various characterization technologies. At last, these catalysts were used in CO2 hydrogenation into methanol to show the effect of hydrothermal treatments on catalytic activity and selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of hydrothermal environment on Cu-ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst for hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol
